lexUnit.name: dread.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: anticipate with great apprehension or fear.

sentence.text: ` My heart fell to my boots , " Henrietta told another , ` for I dreaded that he was going to choose me and he did . "
It seldom had to ring more than once , but every time he dreaded that the peal might have woken Nell .
He thought of Lucia 's mobile mouth , her often oblique wit , and dreaded that she might start to question , and come to the wrong person 's notice .
She only dreaded that she might be asked to give some positive details of the scheme she and Andrew supposedly envisaged .
He dreaded that it might be unforgivable .
I dreaded that file landing on my desk , and yet to make clear how much I wished to avoid it would …
He dreaded the feel of the big leather belt across his bare legs and buttocks .
Holman 's hand found the soft curve of Casey 's waist and he dreaded the telephone call that might take him away from her .
But here she was beginning to dread these lonely days locked up with the servants who padded around on naked feet and respectfully waited for her to want something .
Mrs Abigail , similarly affected , believed that what she 'd been dreading all day had now come about : the parents of some child had arrived at the bungalow .
She dreaded the end of the fifth year when she would have to leave -- it had been made clear to her that she was not ` sixth form material " .
She got out of the car , dreading the moment when she would have to meet Dana .
Karelius , though dreading what he might hear , confronted him at once .
Dreading what he might see , Rincewind let his gaze slide upwards .
I dread to think who Uncle Joe had transferred his twisted ` affections " to , but at the time , I was just relieved to be free of his attentions .
I dread to think how we would have managed without all their help .
He had always dreaded being singled out as the only boy in the school with nits , a solitary outcast with a shaved head .
We dread facing them because we are frightened of what the other person might say .
But I dread having to get out of bed .
He had been dreading having to look for a place for lunch .
I was dreading telling them -- you ca n't imagine .
I hated arguments and dreaded anyone being cross with me or with anyone else .
You dreaded anyone coming in for fabric because you knew you would n't be able to get more than three yards without a fault . "
DO YOU wake up every morning dreading the decision about what to wear to the office ?
She had been dreading the question ever since its loss .
I was dreading the inevitable hitching to Ullapool .
Christina groaned inwardly , dreading another boring evening with people they had nothing in common with .
She was frankly dreading any further confrontation with the other girl .
Albert equally dreaded the law , for though it would find him the injured one , no court would approve of leaving a five-year-old to the care of its father in an airport hotel .
John has been dreading this moment .
They dreaded the prospect of accepting , but they were fond of their father , so they generally packed warm clothes and went .
I had come to dread that word -- not that I was n't all in favour of efficiency generally but I did feel that there were times when other criteria applied .
It was almost a relief to be being attacked on this particular issue , because there were other far more personal ones to be dreaded .
But they have dreaded the day terrorism would strike .
` We all dread the day assignments come out .
I loved to stop for the night but dreaded the effort of making camp .
Anyone who dreads the hairdressers more than the dentists can be guaranteed a warm welcome at Greys with free advice available .

The whole day had been a great strain and although they had attempted to resolve their differences and clear the air Rachel found herself dreading the prospect of working with David Markham on a permanent basis .
` Let me put it this way , Sir Robert , if Moodie dreaded our return then he had very little to fear . "
He dreaded the thought of having to spend three weeks in the middle of the kitchens , never once out of the maýtre chef de cuisine 's sight , but he accepted there was no alternative .
Yet at the same time it reminded her all too clearly of something she was dreading more and more .
` This was the moment we have always dreaded , " said 61-year-old Mrs Harrison , of Eccles , Greater Manchester .
There was another punishment I dreaded .
Once the cow was milked , the chickens fed and the eggs collected , Agnes faced the task that she dreaded .
